Notes: heart as part of a person's body

Gloss: to be good, to be beautiful
to be smart, to be happy

Notes: Tone varies by context; given is for 'mə nɛn zi'

Covers the general act of eating; also covers winning in certain circumstances, e.g. an election, a contest, or a lottery.  This is a single entry since I believe "to eat" and "to win" are polysemous, not homophonous.
Tone varies by context; those provided match "mə zi kɔ arian nɛnɑ̃"
The /ŋga/ is the same as the word for vein, nerve, or tendon

Gloss: to kick gently, to push with foot, to push

Notes: Tone varies by context; tone provided is for "mə nɛn zi".
Tone varies by context; given is for /mə jən mʙɯ/

This dance is apparently performed at memorial (funeral) ceremonies by friends/relatives of deceased (?).  Dance has mystic powers?  Some people think that you should not touch people dancing the kuʔŋga.  Superstition also says something like if a kuʔŋga dancer plants a banana tree, the tree will grow very quickly so that the dancer may pick a banana while still dancing... need clarification on all this!

Only refers to a specific type/species of mosquito (apparently a kind found in the village, rather than in the city).  Also: informant first provided /moskito/, had to be reminded of the existence of this word
/g/ manifests as /ɣ/

Gloss: to be dry; to become thin or skinny, to lose weight
Notes: Seems to have a negative or sickly connotation, as in getting thin from illness.
Plural.  Something like “tree potatoes”?  Apparently /ndɑm/ is something like sweet potatoes.
Probably “tree seed”; /zwit/ seems to be separate morpheme, “something you have to plant”
Loan word? /r/ to /nd/?
Literally “forest meat,” seems to cover the meat of any non-domesticated animal-- example given was monkey meat.
Why does CEPOM have a schwa at the end?
Seems to refer to a wide, flat tail: apparently birds and fish have /swa/, while dogs do not
Seems to refer to a long, narrow tail: dogs have /nkʰwɵn/ while birds and fish do not
Literally "water eye"?
It seems to be necessary to include a possessor
Apparently homonymous with plural of “tree”
It seems to be necessary to include a possessor
Covers sucking through a straw; unsure about other semantic domains

Gloss: to snort, to inhale through nose
Notes: Not sure about the semantic realm of this verb-- definitely covers the act of inhaling a powder nasally, e.g. cocaine

Literally “to throw spit,” apparently.  In rapid speech sounds more like /tɑɣnsi/. Strange tone pattern for a verb; seems like the last syllable of most verbs is high.  Probably because this is a sort of compound, or maybe /ntsi/ is the object of the verb.
Not to be confused with “to kill”: /nə zwi/ with tones 3,5
Not to be confused with "to laugh", /nə zwi/ with tones 3,35
It seems that the underlying form of this might actually begin with /ʙ/, since I've never heard it surface as /b/ and it's not intervocalic in isolation.  More data needed.
Same vowel as “tree”
Not sure if the semantic realm of this word covers scratching with things other than fingernails.
Strange tone pattern; most verbs end high

Gloss: to lie down, to be lying down
Notes: Not sure if this covers the state of lying down, the act of lying down, or both

Gloss: to sit down, to be sitting down
Notes: Not sure if this covers the state of sitting, the act of sitting, or both
Covers the state of standing and the act of standing
Seems to apply to non-humans-- examples for this verb include paper, trees, birds, possibly dogs
Seems to apply to humans, maybe exclusively?

Gloss: to flow, to spill, to trickle
Notes: Seems to cover the movement of any liquid-- examples include liquid flowing off a plate, a spilled bucket of milk, water leaking out of a bottle
Literally “mother of the month”
Loanword from English “sand”; original Medumba word unknown
Not sure what differentiates /fjak/ and /fɯtmbaŋ/.  /fjak/ may be a wind that’s distinctly cold.
Not sure what differentiates /fjak/ and /fɯtmbaŋ/.  /fɯtmbaŋ/ may be a strong wind, storm, or tornado.

Gloss: to burn, to roast, to put in fire, to spit-roast

Notes: Apparently derived from “grass”
Not sure what the semantic range of this verb is-- applies at least to a bowl full of liquid
Literally "not good"?

Gloss: to be dull, to be not sharp

Notes: Not sure what the semantic range of this verb is-- it applies to hair, cloth, smooth wood, maybe not skin

Gloss: to dry, to make dry, to cause to become dry

Notes: Apparently has a non-sickly connotation-- /akak/ is a person who is normally thin, whereas a person who has become thin from illness would use /nə ʒumɑ/

Gloss: close, near, not far from speaker

Notes: Interestingly, in this word /ɣ/ does not surface as /g/ even in slow speech.
Polysemy with /nə sagə/ "to be long"?
Seems to break down into "hand right
Related to /zə/ "that"?
Some type of parasite that grows on trees and looks like a tree’s bark... maybe a fungus or lichen?
Speaker posits tɔ to be the same morpheme as “father”, and tʃuʔ to be “something round under the skin,” maybe a lump or tumor?
Refers to love in general, not specifically romantic love or family love
Speaker hesitated to produce this word without a possessor.  Differs from CEPOM dictionary entry for skull.
In the CEPOM dictionary, this word is translated as “eyebrow”, not “eyelid”.  Not sure which is correct.
CEPOM dictionary lists this word as meaning “beard” but not “moustache”.  Consultant says it refers to all facial hair.  Meaning shift or confusion?
CEPOM lists /nkibbu/, which sounds like a plural, as singular “ongle du doigt”.  Is that a mistake on their part or an error by consultant?

Idiomatic-- apparently /djaɣə/ means “to find” or “to look at”, and /ndʒa/ means “trouble”, thus this word for index finger refers somehow to a finger that points at or finds trouble.  Consultant says she learned this word as a little girl, but is unsure whether it’s still used.
Apparently homophonous with “needle” according to consultant
Consultant provided this word for “lungs,” but CEPOM glosses it as “respiration, âme”.  When prompted for “âme” consultant also provided this word.  Also: said /zwjak sɑm/, so that’s its possessor
Consultant says: “the verb is /nə swɛnɑ̃/, but in a sentence the /s/ comes like /z/ sometimes”
Minimal tone pair with “spit” /ntsi/
Use of /bə/ implies hearer's knowledge of where "bə" is. Consultant says: "If you say 'where is my book?' and I say 'mə jɑp bə,' it means that you know where I am supposed to put it."

Gloss: to get sick, to be sick
to pass, to surpass, to be superior

Notes: Seems to function as a comparative marker

Gloss: to be strong, to be hard, to be difficult

Notes: New coining-- apparently means ‘city’, ‘town’, ‘school’, any ‘really new thing’
Consultant first provided /nə kwɯt/ when prompted for “to build”, then quickly corrected herself and said this

Gloss: to stay, to live (in a house)

Notes: The name of our Medumba consultant, and so a frequent stand-in name for elicitation sentences.
Seems to be literally “not hear”.  Consultant says /kətʃup/ “mute” (lit. not speak) is a more common word to describe the deaf, since deafness and muteness often co-occur.
Consultant says /kətʃup/  is a more common word than /kəʒuʔ/ to describe the deaf, since deafness and muteness often co-occur.
Consultant says /nfɯ/ means something like “pretend”, and that /nfɯmjak/ means something like “pretend eyes, eyes that give the illusion of having eyes.”

Odd tones here-- usually verbs end on a high tone.  Possibly a result of this being a compound verb?  Consultant says /nə njuʔu/ is something like “to press something”, so could this have a literal meaning “to suppress laughter”?

Gloss: to press something, to push something

Notes: Speaker provides first /nə samvɯlɒ/ and then corrects to /nə samvɯt/.  /vɯt/ is apparently “body” or “skin”, looks to be an object of the verb /sam/ “to massage”.  So maybe this is more like “to massage one’s body”?
/vɯt/ is apparently “body” or “skin”, looks to be an object of the verb /njɪt/.  Speaker refers to verb as /nə njɪlə/ “to pull, to stretch” without the /vɯt/.

Gloss: to stretch something, to pull something
to talk, to speak, to discuss
to be loud, to make a lot of noise
Notes: Applications of this word include: water in the ocean, cars, groups of children

Gloss: to shave, to peel with a knife
Notes: This seems to cover the act of using a tool to remove a layer of something from a surface-- need to get more specifics.  Refers to shaving and also peeling.  This verb covers peeling a potato or carrot, but NOT peeling a banana. If one peels an orange with a knife, it’s /kumɑ̃/, but not if one peels it with hands. Consultant says “it has something to do with the way you hold the knife.”
Refers to peeling something with one’s hands, not a tool.  Examples of things that can be /ʒubə/: orange, banana
Received this word when asking what the verb for skinning an animal would be; however, consultant glosses it as “to move something” and also “to keep something”.
Looks like bɒʔ “to braid” is taking tʃu “head” as its object here.

Gloss: to braid, to weave, to knit
Notes: This seems to cover braiding hair, braiding plant fibers, weaving, knitting.  Maybe everything wherein fibers are somehow intertwined?
/vɯt/ is apparently “body” or “skin”, looks to be an object of the verb /sɔk/.
Refers not only to combing hair, but anything that one uses a comb on, including artificial hair and weaving fibers
Probably derived from /nə salə/ “to comb” and /tʃu/ “head”

Apparently this is one of many words that have the general meaning of “to insult,” but consultant can’t remember any others.  She says this is homophonous (or maybe polysemous?) with a verb /tʃobə/ which means something like “to mash,” which is often used with /mba/, “the fruit which gives palm oil;” if someone says “you /tʃob/ me,” a common response is “no, mə tʃob mba” (“no, I mash the fruit which gives palm oil.”)
Literally “insult mouth”?

Gloss: to like, to love, to envy

Notes: Seems to break down into “child” and “evil, bad”
Lit. “to have pain in the heart”
This seems to be a verb /bɯ/ plus the noun for "happiness".  CEPOM lists /nə tsiaŋdə/ for "etre joyeux".

Gloss: to lie, to tell a lie

Notes: Hazy semantics here-- example given for this verb was someone who’s paid by the hour and works less than the time they demand payment for.  Maybe related to /nfɯmjak/ “blind”?
Pronoun that can be: he/she/it

to be smart, to be intelligent, to be happy

Gloss: to be stingy, to be miserly, to be greedy
Notes: When explaining this word’s meaning, consultant says “this is when you have something, but you don’t give it to anyone, and you can’t even eat it by yourself... like you have money, and you are hungry, but you just take one dollar and buy... and you don’t give it to someone. You don’t spend.”
Looks oddly like a verb, but tone doesn't pattern like a verb, and consultant provided it for "truth," said it did not mean "to tell the truth"

Gloss: to be sneaky, to be sly
Notes: CEPOM glosses this as "etre sournois".  /nə ŋuʔdə/ apparently means something like to hide an item, to keep it for oneself, to hoard something; presumably this just means “to /ŋuʔdə/ something”? Example given was someone having a visa to travel to Paris, and traveling without telling anyone... perhaps this has more to do with keeping knowledge hidden?
Elicited was “to greet... like to greet someone when they come to your house.”

Gloss: to be nice, to be kind

Notes: literally "girl of mother." rarely used in isolation
